user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_get_free:
```c
size_t
MHD_pool_get_free (struct MemoryPool *pool)
{
  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
#ifdef MHD_ASAN_POISON_ACTIVE
  if ((pool->end - pool->pos) <= _MHD_RED_ZONE_SIZE)
    return 0;
#endif /* MHD_ASAN_POISON_ACTIVE */
  return (pool->end - pool->pos) - _MHD_RED_ZONE_SIZE;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_pool_get_free:
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
...
#define ROUND_TO_ALIGN(n) (((n)+(ALIGN_SIZE-1))/(ALIGN_SIZE)*(ALIGN_SIZE))
...
#define _MHD_RED_ZONE_SIZE (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined the function MHD_pool_get_free and the related macro definitions. There is no use of the standard library function memcmp (nor of any other string-comparison functions such as strcmp/strncmp) in the target function or in the provided related macros. The code only performs integer/size arithmetic and conditional checks: mhd_assert is defined to ((void)0) (no runtime call), ROUND_TO_ALIGN performs numeric alignment arithmetic, and _MHD_RED_ZONE_SIZE is defined as 0. The optional MHD_ASAN_POISON_ACTIVE block contains no string operations. Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 (prohibition of memcmp to compare null-terminated strings).
